description: Tiny silver fish (dulong) mixed with egg, flour, and spices, then pan-fried into patties. A delicious breakfast or side dish, often dipped in ketchup or vinegar.
steps: In a bowl, mix dulong, eggs, flour, garlic, onion, spring onions, salt, and pepper.
Heat oil in a pan.
Scoop spoonfuls of the mixture into the pan.
Fry until golden brown on both sides.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve with vinegar or ketchup.

title: Tokwa't Baboy
summary: Fried tofu and boiled pork ears in a soy-vinegar dressing.
description: A classic appetizer or side dish for lugaw/congee. Cubes of fried tofu and tender pork (ears or belly) are tossed in a mixture of soy sauce, vinegar, chopped onions, and chili.

ingredients.name: Pork belly or ears, boiled and cubed

steps: Fry tofu until golden and crispy. Set aside.
Boil pork until tender. Slice into cubes.
In a bowl, mix soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, onions, and chili.
Combine fried tofu and pork in a serving dish.
Pour the sauce over the mixture.
Serve as pulutan or side dish.

title: Inihaw na Liempo
summary: Marinated grilled pork belly served with spicy vinegar.
description: Juicy pork belly strips marinated in soy sauce, calamansi, garlic, and pepper, then grilled over charcoal until smoky and tender. The fat renders down to a crispy, flavorful delight.
steps: Combine soy sauce, calamansi, garlic, pepper, and oil.
Marinate pork belly for at least 3 hours.
Grill over charcoal or in a grill pan.
Cook for 5-7 minutes per side until cooked through and charred.
Let rest for 5 minutes before slicing.
Serve with spiced vinegar and rice.

title: Bibingka
summary: Traditional rice cake cooked in banana leaves with salted egg and cheese.
description: A Christmas favorite. Rice flour batter is poured into banana leaf-lined clay pots and baked with coals on top and bottom. Topped with salted egg slices, cheese, and grated coconut.
steps: Whisk eggs and sugar until creamy.
Add rice flour, baking powder, coconut milk, and water. Mix until smooth.
Line molds with banana leaves.
Pour batter into molds.
Top with salted egg and cheese.
Bake in oven at 375°F (190°C) for 20-25 minutes.
Brush with butter and top with grated coconut.
Serve warm.

title: Puto Bumbong
summary: Steamed purple rice cake served with butter, sugar, and coconut.
description: Another Simbang Gabi staple. Made from purple glutinous rice (pirurutong) steamed in bamboo tubes. Served with margarine or butter, muscovado sugar, and grated coconut.
steps: Soak rice mixture overnight. Grind slightly to make coarse flour.
Wrap in cloth and drain excess water.
Fill bamboo tubes (bumbong) with the mixture.
Steam for a few minutes until cooked.
Push out of the tube.
Spread butter, sprinkle sugar and coconut.
Serve hot.

title: Banana Cue
summary: Deep-fried saba bananas coated in caramelized brown sugar.
description: The quintessential Filipino street food. Saba bananas are deep-fried, then brown sugar is added to the oil to caramelize and coat the bananas. Skewered on bamboo sticks.
steps: Heat oil in a deep pan.
Add bananas and fry for 2 minutes.
Sprinkle brown sugar into the oil.
Wait for sugar to melt and float.
Stir bananas to coat them in the caramelized sugar.
Remove and drain slightly.
Skewer on bamboo sticks (2 per stick).

title: Homemade Taho
summary: Silken tofu with sweet syrup and sago pearls.
description: A beloved morning snack usually sold by peddlers. Soft silken tofu is topped with arnibal (brown sugar syrup) and sago pearls. This recipe uses store-bought silken tofu for an easy homemade version.
steps: Make syrup (Arnibal): Boil water, brown sugar, and vanilla until slightly thick.
Steam silken tofu for 10-15 minutes to heat through.
Scoop thin layers of tofu into a cup.
Add cooked sago pearls.
Pour hot syrup over the tofu.
Mix and enjoy warm.

title: Kwek-Kwek
summary: Boiled quail eggs coated in orange batter and deep-fried.
description: A popular street food. Hard-boiled quail eggs are dipped in an orange-colored batter (flour, cornstarch, annatto) and deep-fried until crispy. Served with vinegar or sweet sauce.
steps: Mix flour, cornstarch, baking powder, annatto, salt, pepper, and water to make a smooth batter.
Dredge quail eggs in a little flour.
Dip eggs into the batter.
Deep fry until crispy and orange.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve with spiced vinegar.

title: Pancit Malabon
summary: Thick rice noodles with seafood sauce, oysters, and squid.
description: Similar to Palabok but uses thicker noodles and the sauce is mixed in, not poured on top. Loaded with seafood like oysters, squid, and shrimp, reflecting Malabon's fishing heritage.

ingredients.name: Thick rice noodles, soaked and boiled

steps: In a large wok, combine shrimp juice, annatto oil, and fish sauce. Bring to a boil.
Add the cooked noodles and toss until fully coated with the sauce.
Transfer to a platter.
Top generously with shrimp, squid, oysters, tinapa, chicharon, eggs, and cabbage.
Serve with calamansi.

title: Suman Malagkit
summary: Sticky rice cake wrapped in banana leaves.
description: A classic kakanin. Glutinous rice is cooked in coconut milk and sugar, wrapped in banana leaves, and steamed. Chewy, sweet, and fragrant.
steps: Soak rice for 1 hour. Drain.
In a pan, cook rice with coconut milk, sugar, and salt until half-cooked and liquid is absorbed.
Prepare banana leaves (pass over flame to soften).
Place 2-3 tbsp of rice mixture on a leaf.
Fold tightly into a log shape.
Steam for 45 minutes to 1 hour.
Serve with sugar or latik.

title: Hardinera (Quezon Meatloaf)
summary: Festive meatloaf from Lucban, Quezon, steamed in oval tins.
description: Often confused with Embutido or Menudo, but it's a distinct dish. Diced pork is cooked menudo-style, then mixed with eggs and steamed in llaneras (oval tins) lined with decorative toppings like pineapple and peppers.
steps: Sauté pork with garlic and onions.
Add tomato sauce and liver spread. Simmer until cooked. Let cool.
Mix in raw eggs, cheese, raisins, pineapple, and peppers.
Grease llaneras (molds). Arrange boiled egg slices and peppers at the bottom for decoration.
Pour pork mixture into molds.
Cover with foil and steam for 45 minutes.
Invert onto a plate to serve.

title: Goto (Beef Tripe Porridge)
summary: Rice porridge with tender beef tripe, ginger, and garlic.
description: A variation of lugaw using beef tripe (tuwalya) and sometimes beef innards. Hearty, warming, and perfect with a side of Tokwa't Baboy.
steps: Boil tripe with ginger until very tender (1.5 - 2 hours). Slice into strips.
Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger.
Add tripe and rice. Sauté for a minute.
Add beef stock. Simmer until rice is cooked and porridge is thick.
Season with fish sauce and safflower.
Serve with toasted garlic, spring onions, and calamansi.

title: Manong's Fishball Sauce
summary: The legendary sweet and spicy brown sauce for street food.
description: You can't have fishballs, kikiam, or kwek-kwek without this sauce. A simple mixture of water, soy sauce, sugar, and cornstarch, simmered until thick and glossy.
steps: In a pot, mix water, soy sauce, sugar, cornstarch, flour, garlic, and onion.
Whisk until smooth and no lumps remain.
Place over medium heat.
Stir constantly until the mixture boils and thickens.
Add chili if you want it spicy.
Simmer for 2 minutes.
Serve as a dip for fried street foods.
